G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the plaintiff resides in this county, and the events giving rise to this complaint occurred at the Defendant's business location in Somerville, Massachusetts.

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.,* 448 Mass. 780, 783 (2007).
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owes a duty of reasonable care to business invitees, including Plaintiff, to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition and to promptly address and/or warn of dangerous conditions.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states Massachusetts premises-liability law for store owners, citing Mounsey and related cases, and describes a store owner’s duty to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to take steps to prevent or remedy hazards. Although the case’s main innovation is adopting the mode-of-operation approach to notice, it reaffirms that the owner’s duty is one of reasonable care to invitees regarding dangerous conditions on the premises. Thus it supports the cited general duty proposition.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973). … This court has thus held that premises liability attaches only if a store owner has actual or constructive notice of the existence of the dangerous condition, sufficient to allow time for the owner to remedy the condition.”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.,* 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant’s negligence constitutes a violation of its duties under Massachusetts common law and statutory law, as set forth in cases such as *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.,* 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973), and *Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.,* 400 Mass. 837, 841 (1987).
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: Oliveri is a common-law premises-liability case defining the duty of one who controls business premises to exercise due care to keep them in reasonably safe condition or to warn of dangers. It does not address any statutory duties, nor does it involve or discuss statutory law at all. Thus it supports only the common-law component of the proposition, and using it as authority for a combined ‘common law and statutory law’ duty overstates what the case actually holds.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “1. The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.,* 400 M.proposition: Defendant’s negligence constitutes a violation of its duties under Massachusetts common law and statutory law, as set forth in cases such as *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.,* 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973), and *Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.,* 400 Mass. 837, 841 (1987).
*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.,* 400 M.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence in Young addresses the existence and scope of a *duty* to warn of obvious risks on self-service gas station premises, concluding that there is no such duty. It does not state or suggest that defendant’s negligence constitutes a violation of Massachusetts common-law or statutory duties in the way the proposition frames it; rather, it finds no duty and thus no negligence on these facts. Using Young here as affirmative authority that negligence violates such duties mischaracterizes the opinion’s thrust.
*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.,* 400 M.relevant_excerpt: “In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.,* 457 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that premises owners must exercise reasonable care to protect lawful visitors from hazardous conditions that they knew or should have known about.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.,* 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that, under Massachusetts premises liability law, a property owner owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and to protect them from dangerous conditions the owner knew or reasonably should have known about. The court abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction precisely to apply this ordinary reasonable-care duty—including knowledge or constructive knowledge of hazards—to snow and ice conditions. This directly aligns with the proposition about premises owners’ duties to lawful visitors regarding known or knowable hazardous conditions.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.,* 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Greene v. Boston Housing Auth.,* 10 Mas.raw_text: *Greene v. Boston Housing Auth.,* 10 Mass. App. Ct. 411, 416 (1980)
*Greene v. Boston Housing Auth.,* 10 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s failure to address or warn of the spilled milk is further established as negligence under Massachusetts precedents, including but not limited to *Greene v. Boston Housing Auth.,* 10 Mass. App. Ct. 411, 416 (1980) and *Dubois v. Powdrell, 271 Mass. 394, 396 (1930).
*Greene v. Boston Housing Auth.,* 10 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion in Greene v. Boston Housing Auth. does not involve premises liability, spills, warnings, or negligence standards regarding dangerous conditions such as spilled milk. It addresses evidentiary issues in a criminal arson prosecution (scope of examination about inducements to a witness and timing of joint enterprise instructions). Therefore, it does not establish or affirm any negligence principle relevant to failure to address or warn of a spill, and the citation is inapt for the stated proposition.
*Greene v. Boston Housing Auth.,* 10 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The defendant Young was convicted by a jury on indictments charging him with arson (G. L. c. 266, § 2) and arson with intent to defraud an insurer (G. L. c. 266, §10)… Young’s appeal raises two issues: (1) Was an inquiry by the Commonwealth on direct examination of Lincoln into rewards and inducements offered to him in exchange for his cooperation so wide ranging as to be unfairly prejudicial to the defendant? (2) Was the timing of a preliminary instruction to the jury about joint criminal enterprise so out of joint as to constitute error?

*Dubois v. Powdrell, 271 Mass. 394, 396.proposition: Defendant’s failure to address or warn of the spilled milk is further established as negligence under Massachusetts precedents, including but not limited to *Greene v. Boston Housing Auth.,* 10 Mass. App. Ct. 411, 416 (1980) and *Dubois v. Powdrell, 271 Mass. 394, 396 (1930).
*Dubois v. Powdrell, 271 Mass. 394, 396.support_reasoning: Dubois v. Powdrell is an automobile negligence and agency case involving a child pedestrian and a minor driver; it does not concern premises liability, spills, or a duty to warn of transient hazards like spilled milk. The opinion addresses contributory negligence of a child and whether the minor driver was acting as his mother’s agent, not any duty to discover, correct, or warn of a spill. Citing Dubois as Massachusetts precedent establishing negligence for failure to address or warn of spilled milk misrepresents the holding and context of the case.
*Dubois v. Powdrell, 271 Mass. 394, 396.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff, a minor, by her next friend, brought an action of tort against Robert Powdrell, a minor, another against Ethel Powdrell, his mother, and a third against Fred A. Powdrell, his father, to recover damages for personal injuries alleged to have been caused by the negligence of the minor defendant in driving an automobile owned by his mother."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
